Thanks for the reply.  Your proposed solution would not solve the problem I
am trying to address.  My situation is the following:

1. My test method throws an exception.  This exception indicates the real
problem.
2. My tearDown method throws an exception.  This exception is caused by an
invalid state because my test method did not run all way through.

This is a problem because of #2.  The way the JUnit framework is written,
any exception coming out of tearDown will mask any exception coming out of a
test method.

Remember that fail() is really just a method that throws an
AssertionFailedError.  So, your solution below will still cause the
exception thrown from tearDown to mask the exception thrown by fail() in the
test method.

In my case the exception thrown in the test method is the root of the
problem.  But, I can't see that exception without modifying my code to print
the exception.  Once I fix the problem, I have to go back and remove the
code I added to print the exception.

Matt

Hi Matt,

JUnit behaves in the following way for catching Exceptions and a 
little modification in the test code would help solving your problem.
 
1) public void testFoo() throws SomeDBException{
     //Some code that would throw SomeDBException
   }

JUnit would automatically catch the Exception and display that as an 
Error (denoted by E in the output). In the description below it would 
give details about this Exception.

2) public void testFoo(){
      try{
        //Some code that would throw SomeDBException
      }
      catch(SomeDBException e){
        //Option I  - Nothing
        //Option II -
        fail("SomeDBException caught");
      }

In this second case when SomeDBException is thrown with Option I, 
JUnit would assume that you are trying to catch this Exception and 
assuming that this is a negative test would 'PASS' the test.

In this second case when Option II is put into effect by giving a 
specific fail() command, JUnit makes the method to 'FAIL'.

Out of the two of the above, if you are really not interested in 
catching the Exeption then it should be just declared to be thrown 
and not explicitly caught and then JUnit would give you the result 
the way you want it.

If you are doing this all and still getting the mentioned 
SomeDBException then that means something needs to be investigated 
further.

I would never modify the Production code in order to make my tests 
pass or fail.

- Nilesh
